metadata.note: Based on original Commission proposal. Danish Council Presidency released updated text on 2025-12-05. Updates may modify specific provisions.

enforcement.alternative_fine_basis: Twice the profit gained or losses avoided from non-compliance
enforcement.appeal: Board of Appeal within EUSPA, then Court of Justice of the EU

spacecraft_operator.definition: Entity that operates or controls a spacecraft in orbit

launch_operator.definition: Entity that operates launch vehicles for the purpose of launching space objects

launch_site_operator.definition: Entity that operates or manages a launch facility

isos_provider.definition: Provider of in-space operations and services (debris removal, on-orbit servicing, etc.)

collision_avoidance_provider.definition: Provider of collision avoidance services to space operators

primary_data_provider.definition: Entity that is the primary provider of space-based data used in the EU
examples: Ground station operators channeling satellite data to EU users

third_country_operator.definition: Space operator established outside the EU providing space services or space-based data in the EU

small_enterprise.definition: As defined in Commission Recommendation 2003/361/EC: <50 employees and <€10M turnover

research_education.definition: Research and educational institutions operating space objects

special_provisions: Some proportionality provisions but NOT eligible for light regime
Standard authorization per satellite or simplified if identical design

titles.name: General Provisions
titles.summary: Subject matter, scope, free movement clause, national security preservation, and key definitions

articles_detail.title: Subject Matter
articles_detail.summary: Establishes rules for internal market of space-based data and space services. Covers: authorization/registration/supervision, orbit traffic management, governance/enforcement, Union Space Label.
articles_detail.operator_action: none

articles_detail.title: Scope
articles_detail.summary: Applies to: space operators, collision avoidance providers, primary data providers, international organizations. Excludes: defense/national security objects, objects launched before 2030-01-01, radio spectrum management. Title IV Chapters I and V do not apply beyond GEO.
articles_detail.operator_action: Determine if your activities fall within scope

questions.question: Do you operate, launch, or provide space-based services or data?
questions.if_yes: In scope (proceed to further questions)

questions.question: Are your space objects used exclusively for defense or national security?
questions.if_yes: Excluded from scope (Art. 2(3)(a))

questions.question: Were your assets launched before January 1, 2030?
questions.if_yes: Pre-existing assets excluded (Art. 2(3)(d))

questions.question: Do you provide space services or space-based data to users in the EU?
questions.if_yes: In scope even if established outside EU (extraterritorial application)

articles_detail.title: Free Movement
articles_detail.summary: Member States cannot restrict provision of space-based data and space services by imposing stricter standards on safety, resilience, sustainability, except in objectively necessary cases.
articles_detail.operator_action: none

articles_detail.title: National Security
articles_detail.summary: Preserves Member States' competence regarding national security matters.
articles_detail.operator_action: none

articles_detail.title: Definitions
articles_detail.summary: Key definitions: space operator, spacecraft, launch vehicle, constellation, space services, space activities, space-based data, Union space operator, third country operator, etc. Note: Greenberg Traurig analysis found definitions 'largely circular'.
articles_detail.operator_action: Determine your classification under the definitions

key_definitions.space_services: Umbrella term including space activities plus ground-based operations like launch infrastructure, collision avoidance, ISOS
key_definitions.space_activities: Operations carried out in outer space
key_definitions.union_space_operator: Space operator established in EU or controlled by EU-established entity
key_definitions.third_country_operator: Space operator established outside EU providing space services/data in EU
key_definitions.constellation: Coordinated group of spacecraft operating as a system
key_definitions.primary_provider_space_based_data: Intermediary channeling space-based data to EU users

questions.question: Is your entity established in the EU?
questions.if_yes: Classified as Union space operator
questions.if_no: Classified as third country operator (if providing services in EU)

questions.question: What type of space services do you provide?

titles.name: Authorization and Registration for Space Activities
titles.summary: Authorization of EU operators (Ch. I), EU-owned assets (Ch. II), third country registration (Ch. III), URSO and e-certificate (Ch. IV)

articles_detail.title: Authorization Requirement
articles_detail.summary: Union space operators may ONLY provide space services in the EU if authorized in one Member State. Authorization demonstrates compliance with Title IV requirements. Single authorization valid across all Member States (mutual recognition).
articles_detail.operator_action: Obtain authorization from NCA before commencing space activities
articles_detail.timeline: NCA must decide within 12 months of complete application

questions.question: Are you established in the EU (or controlled by an EU entity)?
questions.if_yes: Must obtain authorization under Chapter I (Art. 6-10)
questions.if_no: Subject to registration under Chapter III (Art. 14-23)

questions.question: In which Member State is your primary establishment?
questions.note: This determines your primary NCA for authorization

articles_detail.title: Authorization Application Procedure
articles_detail.summary: Application must include: technical file demonstrating compliance with Title IV Ch. I-V, identification of QTBs to be used, mission profile details. Application transmitted to NCA. NCA may seek technical assessment from EUSPA if no national QTBs available.
articles_detail.operator_action: Prepare and submit authorization application with complete technical file
required_documents: Technical file demonstrating Title IV compliance
Identification of chosen Qualified Technical Bodies (QTBs)

questions.question: Does your Member State have designated QTBs for space activities?
questions.if_yes: Use national QTBs for technical assessment
questions.if_no: EUSPA Compliance Board provides technical assessment

articles_detail.title: Authorization Decision
articles_detail.summary: NCA grants or refuses authorization. If granted, operator registered in URSO. Authorization may include conditions. NCA informs EUSPA of all authorized operators.
articles_detail.operator_action: Receive authorization decision, comply with any conditions

articles_detail.title: Constellation Authorization (Simplified)
articles_detail.summary: Simplified single-authorization procedure for satellite constellations of identical design. One authorization covers entire constellation based on assessment of single satellite. Authorities retain right to inspect others.
articles_detail.operator_action: Apply for constellation authorization if operating uniform constellation

questions.question: Do you operate a constellation of satellites?
questions.if_yes: Proceed to constellation assessment

questions.question: Are all satellites in your constellation of identical design?
questions.if_yes: Eligible for simplified constellation authorization (Art. 9)
questions.if_no: Each satellite variant may need separate authorization

articles_detail.title: Light Regimes and Exemptions
articles_detail.summary: Three light regimes for eligible operators. Adjusted authorization conditions for safety, resilience, sustainability. Eligibility based on: (1) small-sized enterprise, (2) research/educational institution, (3) missions posing low risk. Proportionality: considers mission type, orbit, constellation size, entity size, risk exposure.
articles_detail.operator_action: Assess eligibility for light regime and apply if qualifying

questions.question: Is your entity a small-sized enterprise (<50 employees, <€10M turnover)?
questions.if_yes: Eligible for light regime on resilience and sustainability (NOT safety)

questions.question: Is your entity a research or educational institution?
questions.if_yes: Eligible for light regime on resilience and sustainability

questions.question: Does your mission pose a low overall risk (considering orbit, size, services)?
questions.if_yes: May qualify for adjusted conditions

decision_logic.important_note: Light regime does NOT exempt from safety obligations. Only resilience and sustainability requirements may be simplified.

articles_detail.title: Authorization of Union-Owned Asset Operators
articles_detail.summary: Operators intending to operate or launch EU-owned assets (e.g., Galileo, Copernicus, IRIS2 constellation) require authorization from the Commission (not Member State NCA). EUSPA provides technical assessment.
articles_detail.operator_action: If operating EU-owned assets, apply to Commission for authorization

questions.question: Are you operating or launching assets owned by the European Union (EU Space Programme assets)?
questions.if_yes: Authorization from European Commission required (Art. 11-13)

articles_detail.title: Supervision of Union-Owned Assets
articles_detail.summary: Commission carries out ongoing supervision of operators of Union-owned assets.
articles_detail.operator_action: Maintain continuous compliance, cooperate with Commission supervision

articles_detail.title: Suspension/Withdrawal of Authorization (Union-Owned Assets)
articles_detail.summary: Commission may suspend or withdraw authorization in specified circumstances.
articles_detail.operator_action: Ensure compliance to avoid suspension/withdrawal

articles_detail.title: Registration Requirement for Third Country Operators
articles_detail.summary: Third country operators providing space services or space-based data in the EU must register in URSO. Must demonstrate compliance with technical requirements of Title IV.
articles_detail.operator_action: Register with EUSPA/URSO before providing space services in EU

questions.question: Are you a non-EU space operator providing services or data to EU customers?
questions.if_yes: Must register in URSO (Art. 14)

questions.question: Has the Commission adopted an equivalence decision for your country?
questions.if_yes: Presumed compliant with technical requirements (Art. 105)

articles_detail.title: Registration Application Procedure (Third Country)
articles_detail.summary: Application for registration submitted to EUSPA. Must include demonstration of compliance with technical requirements.
articles_detail.operator_action: Submit registration application to EUSPA

articles_detail.title: EU Legal Representative Requirement
articles_detail.summary: Third country operators must designate a legal representative in the EU to ensure effective cooperation with competent authorities, Commission, and EUSPA.
articles_detail.operator_action: Designate EU-based legal representative

questions.question: Do you already have a legal entity established in the EU?
questions.if_yes: This entity may serve as representative
questions.if_no: Must designate a legal representative in an EU Member State

articles_detail.title: Derogations for Launch Services, Government Entities, Emergency
articles_detail.summary: Specific derogations for: third country launch services (Art. 17), third country governmental entities (Art. 18), single market emergency clause (Art. 19). These provide adjusted requirements for specific scenarios.
articles_detail.operator_action: Assess if any derogation applies to your situation

articles_detail.title: Commission Decisions on Third Country Registration
articles_detail.summary: Commission decides on registration of third country operators (Art. 20), with EUSPA support (Art. 21). Supervision provisions (Art. 22) and suspension/withdrawal (Art. 23).
articles_detail.operator_action: Cooperate with Commission/EUSPA supervision

chapters.name: URSO, e-Certificate, and Provision of Space Services

articles_detail.title: Union Register of Space Objects (URSO)
articles_detail.summary: EUSPA establishes and manages URSO. All authorized/registered operators entered into URSO. Publicly accessible register.
articles_detail.operator_action: Ensure accurate information in URSO

articles_detail.title: e-Certificate
articles_detail.summary: EUSPA issues e-certificates attesting conformity of space-based data/services with Regulation requirements. Required for contracts providing space-based data/services in EU.
articles_detail.operator_action: Obtain e-certificate from EUSPA

articles_detail.title: Provision of Space-Based Data and Services
articles_detail.summary: Contracts for space-based data/services in EU must be accompanied by e-certificate.
articles_detail.operator_action: Ensure all contracts include valid e-certificate

articles_detail.title: Primary Data Provider Notifications
articles_detail.summary: Primary providers of space-based data must notify EUSPA of any suspected irregularities in compliance.
articles_detail.operator_action: Monitor and report irregularities to EUSPA

titles.name: Governance Aspects
titles.summary: National governance (Ch. I: NCAs, QTBs) and Union governance (Ch. II: EUSPA roles, Commission powers, enforcement)

articles_detail.title: National Competent Authorities (NCAs)
articles_detail.summary: Each Member State designates/establishes NCA with sufficient resources and powers for oversight. NCAs have supervisory, investigatory, corrective, and sanctioning powers.
articles_detail.operator_action: Identify your relevant NCA(s)

articles_detail.title: NCA Powers and Functions
articles_detail.summary: NCAs monitor compliance, conduct investigations, cooperate with other Member States' NCAs.
articles_detail.operator_action: Cooperate with NCA oversight activities

articles_detail.title: NCA Sanctioning Powers
articles_detail.summary: NCAs have power to impose sanctions including fines for violations. Fines up to 2% of global annual turnover or twice profit/losses avoided.
articles_detail.operator_action: Maintain compliance to avoid sanctions

articles_detail.title: NCA Cooperation
articles_detail.summary: NCAs cooperate with authorities of other Member States and with EUSPA/Commission.
articles_detail.operator_action: none

articles_detail.title: QTB Designation and Requirements
articles_detail.summary: Member States may designate QTBs for technical assessment of space activities. QTBs must be independent, impartial, technically competent. National accreditation bodies assess QTBs. QTB decisions can be appealed.
articles_detail.operator_action: Identify available QTBs in your Member State for technical assessment during authorization

articles_detail.title: Becoming a QTB
articles_detail.summary: Procedures for entities wishing to become QTBs. Not directly relevant for space operators.
articles_detail.operator_action: none

articles_detail.title: EUSPA New Tasks
articles_detail.summary: EUSPA manages URSO, issues e-certificates, supports Commission in authorization/registration, establishes Compliance Board and Board of Appeal, maintains contact list database for high-interest event alerts.
articles_detail.operator_action: Understand EUSPA as primary interface for registration, certification, and technical assessment

articles_detail.title: EUSPA Internal Structures
articles_detail.summary: Compliance Board supports technical assessments. Board of Appeal safeguards defense rights. Registration fees finance new tasks.
articles_detail.operator_action: Budget for registration fees

sections.name: Commission/EUSPA Powers over Third Country Operators

articles_detail.title: Commission Supervision of Third Country Operators
articles_detail.summary: Commission monitors compliance of registered third country operators, supported by EUSPA.
articles_detail.operator_action: Cooperate with Commission supervision

articles_detail.title: Investigation Powers
articles_detail.summary: Commission and EUSPA share wide investigative powers including on-site inspections of both EU and third country operators.
articles_detail.operator_action: Be prepared for potential on-site inspections. Maintain audit trail.

articles_detail.title: Findings and Corrective Measures
articles_detail.summary: Commission may find infringement and impose corrective measures including suspension/withdrawal of authorization.
articles_detail.operator_action: Maintain compliance to avoid corrective measures

articles_detail.title: Fines and Periodic Penalty Payments
articles_detail.summary: Commission may impose administrative fines (up to 2% global turnover or twice profit/losses) and periodic penalty payments. Right to be heard. Court of Justice has unlimited jurisdiction on appeal.
articles_detail.operator_action: Maintain compliance. Budget for compliance costs significantly lower than potential fines.

titles.name: Technical Requirements
titles.summary: Core technical obligations: safety/sustainability (Ch. I), resilience (Ch. II), environmental sustainability (Ch. III), ISOS (Ch. IV), orbital traffic (Ch. V), standards (Ch. VI)

articles_detail.title: Launch Safety Plan
articles_detail.summary: Launch operators must submit Launch Safety Plan to NCA. Coordinate with air traffic and maritime authorities. Mitigate collision risk during launch and re-entry.
articles_detail.operator_action: Prepare and submit Launch Safety Plan

articles_detail.title: Flight Safety Systems
articles_detail.summary: Launch operators required to install flight safety systems on launch vehicles.
articles_detail.operator_action: Install required flight safety systems

articles_detail.title: Launch Debris Control
articles_detail.summary: Implement space debris control measures during launch. Collision avoidance windows and casualty risk thresholds per Commission implementing acts.
articles_detail.operator_action: Implement debris control measures, calculate collision avoidance windows

articles_detail.title: Re-entry Safety
articles_detail.summary: Ensure safe re-entry of launch vehicle stages. Coordinate re-entry with authorities.
articles_detail.operator_action: Plan and coordinate safe re-entry

articles_detail.title: Trackability
articles_detail.summary: Spacecraft operators must ensure all spacecraft are trackable (detectable by ground-based or space-based sensors).
articles_detail.operator_action: Ensure spacecraft design meets trackability requirements

articles_detail.title: Collision Avoidance Service Subscription
articles_detail.summary: Spacecraft operators must subscribe to collision avoidance services for the duration of their mission.
articles_detail.operator_action: Subscribe to collision avoidance service (EUSST or commercial provider)

articles_detail.title: Re-entry Coordination (Spacecraft)
articles_detail.summary: Coordinate spacecraft re-entry with relevant authorities.
articles_detail.operator_action: Plan and coordinate end-of-life re-entry

articles_detail.title: Manoeuvrability Requirements
articles_detail.summary: Maintain minimum level of manoeuvrability for collision avoidance.
articles_detail.operator_action: Ensure spacecraft has required maneuvering capability

articles_detail.title: Space Debris Mitigation Plan
articles_detail.summary: Draw up comprehensive space debris mitigation plan covering collision avoidance, end-of-life disposal, fragmentation avoidance, passivation. Submit as part of authorization.
articles_detail.operator_action: Prepare and submit debris mitigation plan
plan_must_cover: End-of-life disposal plan (controlled re-entry or graveyard orbit)

articles_detail.title: Light and Radio Pollution Mitigation
articles_detail.summary: Operators must develop pollution mitigation plan for night sky visibility and radio astronomy protection. Visual magnitude must remain at or above 7 throughout operational lifetime.
articles_detail.operator_action: Develop light/radio pollution mitigation plan
articles_detail.note: Enhanced obligations for large constellations (100+ satellites)

articles_detail.title: Large Constellation Additional Requirements
articles_detail.summary: Additional safety and debris mitigation standards for large constellations. Enhanced collision avoidance, comprehensive debris management.
articles_detail.operator_action: Additional compliance requirements if operating large constellation

questions.question: How many satellites are in your constellation?
questions.if_100_plus: Subject to additional large constellation requirements (Art. 69-70)

articles_detail.title: Mission Extension
articles_detail.summary: Operators may request mission extensions if continuing to satisfy end-of-life and debris requirements.
articles_detail.operator_action: Apply for mission extension if needed

articles_detail.title: End-of-Life Requirements
articles_detail.summary: Detailed disposal requirements: controlled re-entry or transfer to graveyard orbit. Deorbit within 25 years (or 5 years for LEO under emerging standards).
articles_detail.operator_action: Plan and execute compliant end-of-life disposal

articles_detail.title: Supply Chain Design/Manufacturing Compliance
articles_detail.summary: Operators must ensure that suppliers and manufacturers comply with design and manufacturing requirements of this chapter.
articles_detail.operator_action: Implement supply chain compliance verification process

articles_detail.title: General Principles and NIS2 Relationship
articles_detail.summary: Comprehensive risk management for all space infrastructure. EU Space Act is lex specialis over NIS2 for space operators classified as essential/important entities. Avoids duplication.
articles_detail.operator_action: Understand relationship between EU Space Act resilience requirements and NIS2

questions.question: Are you already classified as an essential or important entity under NIS2?
questions.if_yes: EU Space Act Ch. II requirements replace NIS2 Art. 21 requirements (lex specialis)
questions.if_no: EU Space Act Ch. II requirements apply independently

articles_detail.title: Risk Management Obligation
articles_detail.summary: All-hazard risk management throughout entire space mission lifecycle (design, manufacturing, launch, operation, disposal). Covers digital and physical threats. Proportionate to operator size and risk profile.
articles_detail.operator_action: Implement comprehensive risk management framework

articles_detail.title: Risk Assessment Requirements
articles_detail.summary: Identify vulnerabilities, implement remediation measures, adapt risk scenarios to each mission. Assess risks to critical assets and functions.
articles_detail.operator_action: Conduct regular risk assessments

articles_detail.title: Information Security and Access Control
articles_detail.summary: Establish information security management policies. Strict access control rights. Physical protection of space assets. Cryptography implementation.
articles_detail.operator_action: Implement information security policies, access control, cryptography

articles_detail.title: Detection, Monitoring, and Incident Response
articles_detail.summary: Incident detection and monitoring capabilities. Backup protocols. Comprehensive business continuity policies and response/recovery plans.
articles_detail.operator_action: Implement incident detection, backup, and business continuity

articles_detail.title: Simplified Risk Management Regime
articles_detail.summary: Lighter measures for operators subject to simplified regime (small enterprises, research institutions). Must still ensure resilience of critical assets/functions. Annex VII point 9 specifies simplified requirements.
articles_detail.operator_action: If eligible for light regime, apply simplified risk management per Annex VII

questions.question: Are you eligible for a light regime under Art. 10?
questions.if_yes: Apply simplified risk management (Annex VII point 9). Focus on: (1) loss of control over propulsion-equipped assets, (2) loss of control over interference-capable assets

articles_detail.title: Incident Reporting
articles_detail.summary: Union space operators must report significant incidents to NCA/EUSPA. Strict timelines for reporting. Operators of Union-owned assets report to EUSPA directly.
articles_detail.operator_action: Establish incident reporting procedures, ensure deadline compliance
articles_detail.deadlines: Reporting within strict timelines (specific timelines to be set in implementing acts)

articles_detail.title: Union Space Resilience Network (EUSRN)
articles_detail.summary: EUSRN facilitates cooperation between Commission, EUSPA, and NCAs. Monitors/handles significant cyber incidents. Aligns with broader EU cybersecurity frameworks.
articles_detail.operator_action: Participate in EUSRN as required, share information on incidents

articles_detail.title: Environmental Footprint (EF) Calculation Obligation
articles_detail.summary: Space operators must calculate environmental footprint throughout space mission lifecycle: design, manufacturing, operations, end-of-life. Unless meeting conditions for exemption.
articles_detail.operator_action: Calculate environmental footprint using LCA methodology
articles_detail.estimated_cost: €4,000-8,000 (Commission estimate for product environmental footprint rules)

questions.question: Are you a small-sized enterprise or research institution?
questions.if_yes: EFD obligation delayed until January 1, 2032 (2-year additional transition)

questions.question: Does your mission meet the conditions for EF exemption?
questions.if_yes: Exemption applies (specific conditions TBD via delegated acts)

articles_detail.title: Environmental Footprint Declaration (EFD)
articles_detail.summary: Submit EFD as part of authorization application. Must include supporting EF studies and data. Verified through EF certificate issued by QTB.
articles_detail.operator_action: Prepare EFD, obtain EF certificate from QTB, submit with authorization application
lca_scope: Design phase: material selection, component sourcing
Launch: propellant type, launch vehicle emissions, ground operations
Operations: station-keeping, power consumption, ground segment energy
End-of-life: de-orbiting fuel, re-entry emissions, debris potential

articles_detail.title: LCA Methodology
articles_detail.summary: Commission will develop space-specific LCA methodology (building on Product Environmental Footprint approach). Currently underdeveloped. Delegated acts to specify.
articles_detail.operator_action: Monitor development of space-specific LCA methodology
articles_detail.note: CRITICAL FOR CAELEX: Early implementation of LCA methodology in software creates strong competitive advantage. Commission acknowledges methodologies are 'underdeveloped'.

articles_detail.title: Supplier Data Requirements
articles_detail.summary: Operators must obtain all relevant environmental data from their suppliers for EF calculation.
articles_detail.operator_action: Require environmental data from all suppliers in supply chain

articles_detail.title: EF Database Submission
articles_detail.summary: Operators send aggregated and disaggregated EF datasets to Commission for inclusion in EU environmental footprint database. Must keep data up to date.
articles_detail.operator_action: Submit EF data to Commission database, maintain current data

articles_detail.title: ISOS Requirements
articles_detail.summary: Spacecraft shall be equipped to receive in-space servicing via dedicated interfaces. Commission will detail design principles. May set debris-removal conditions for threatening objects.
articles_detail.operator_action: Design spacecraft with servicing interfaces per Commission specifications
articles_detail.note: Requirement details to come via implementing acts. Important for future-proofing spacecraft design.

articles_detail.title: Collision Avoidance Manoeuvre Rules
articles_detail.summary: Rules for how collision avoidance maneuvers should be carried out under high-interest event alerts.
articles_detail.operator_action: Implement collision avoidance procedures per orbital traffic rules

articles_detail.title: Right of Way Rules
articles_detail.summary: Introduces right-of-way approach for resolving collisions between multiple maneuverable spacecraft. Designed to prevent ambiguity in collision scenarios.
articles_detail.operator_action: Understand and follow right-of-way rules in conjunction events

articles_detail.title: Technical Standards
articles_detail.summary: Commission may request European standardization organizations to draft standards. Commission may adopt implementing acts for common specifications where standards are insufficient.
articles_detail.operator_action: Monitor and implement new technical standards as they are published
articles_detail.note: CRITICAL FOR CAELEX: Standards will evolve continuously. Regulatory intelligence feed must track all new standards, implementing acts, and delegated acts.

titles.name: Equivalence, International Agreements, International Organizations
titles.summary: Equivalence decisions for third country operators and rules for international organizations

articles_detail.title: Equivalence Decisions
articles_detail.summary: Commission may adopt equivalence decisions recognizing that a third country's regulatory framework provides equivalent level of protection. Third country operators with equivalence benefit are presumed compliant.
articles_detail.operator_action: Check if equivalence decision exists for your country

questions.question: Has the Commission adopted an equivalence decision for your country of establishment?
questions.if_yes: Presumed compliant with technical requirements. Simplified registration.
questions.if_no: Must independently demonstrate compliance with all technical requirements.

articles_detail.title: International Agreements and Organizations
articles_detail.summary: Framework for agreements with international organizations operating Union-owned assets. Rules for international organization compliance.
articles_detail.operator_action: If international organization: check specific provisions

titles.name: Supporting Measures
titles.summary: Support for compliance implementation (Ch. I) and voluntary Union Space Label (Ch. II)

articles_detail.title: Capacity Building
articles_detail.summary: Commission supports capacity building: guidance materials, information portals, vouchers for expert assistance.
articles_detail.operator_action: Take advantage of Commission capacity-building resources

articles_detail.title: Technical Assistance
articles_detail.summary: Pool of independent experts to support space operators in compiling technical dossiers. Especially valuable for startups and SMEs.
articles_detail.operator_action: Request technical assistance from expert pool if needed

articles_detail.title: Digital Solution / Information Portal
articles_detail.summary: Commission funds one-stop information portal for compliance guidance.
articles_detail.operator_action: Use information portal for compliance guidance
articles_detail.note: CAELEX OPPORTUNITY: Position as complement to (not replacement for) official portal. Caelex provides actionable workflow; portal provides official guidance.

articles_detail.title: Union Space Label Framework
articles_detail.summary: Voluntary label for operators meeting HIGHER requirements on safety, resilience, sustainability beyond mandatory minimums. Enhances market reputation.
articles_detail.operator_action: Consider applying for Union Space Label to demonstrate excellence
articles_detail.note: CAELEX FUTURE FEATURE: Help operators achieve Union Space Label as premium service

titles.name: Final Provisions
titles.summary: Delegated/implementing acts, professional secrecy, application dates

articles_detail.title: Delegated and Implementing Acts
articles_detail.summary: Commission empowered to adopt delegated acts (specifying technical details) and implementing acts (common specifications, procedures) throughout implementation.
articles_detail.operator_action: Monitor all delegated and implementing acts for changes to requirements
articles_detail.note: CRITICAL FOR CAELEX: Continuous stream of regulatory updates = continuous product updates = subscription retention

articles_detail.title: Professional Secrecy
articles_detail.summary: Confidentiality obligations for authorities and bodies processing information under the Regulation.
articles_detail.operator_action: Understand confidentiality protections for submitted data

articles_detail.title: Review
articles_detail.summary: Comprehensive evaluation 5 years after entry into force.
articles_detail.operator_action: none

articles_detail.title: Entry into Force and Application
articles_detail.summary: Regulation applies from January 1, 2030. Two-year transitional period for substantive obligations. Small enterprises: additional 2-year transition for EFD (until 2032).

step_1_scope.question: Do you operate spacecraft, launch vehicles, launch sites, provide in-space services, collision avoidance services, or space-based data?
step_1_scope.if_no: EU Space Act does not apply to you.

step_2_defense_exclusion.question: Are your space objects used EXCLUSIVELY for defense or national security?
step_2_defense_exclusion.if_yes: Excluded from scope (Art. 2(3)(a)). However, dual-use assets may still be covered.

step_3_pre2030_assets.question: Were all your assets launched before January 1, 2030?
step_3_pre2030_assets.if_yes: Pre-existing assets excluded (Art. 2(3)(d)). New assets launched after 2030 ARE in scope.

step_4_operator_type.question: What is your primary operator type?

step_5_eu_or_third_country.question: Are you established in the EU (or controlled by an EU-established entity)?
step_5_eu_or_third_country.if_yes: Union space operator: Authorization required (Title II, Ch. I)
step_5_eu_or_third_country.if_no: Third country operator: Registration required (Title II, Ch. III). Must designate EU legal representative.

options.small_enterprise: Eligible for light regime (Art. 10): simplified resilience + EFD delayed to 2032. Safety obligations remain FULL.
options.research_education: Eligible for light regime (Art. 10): similar to small enterprise.
options.medium_enterprise: Some proportionality provisions but NOT eligible for light regime.
options.large_enterprise: Full compliance required across all pillars.

step_7_constellation.question: Do you operate a satellite constellation?

options.2-9: Standard requirements, simplified authorization if identical design
options.100-999: Large constellation: enhanced debris + pollution mitigation mandatory

step_8_orbit.question: What orbit do your assets operate in?

options.Beyond_GEO: Title IV Ch. I and V do NOT apply (Art. 2(2)). Ch. II (resilience) and Ch. III (environmental) still apply.

ongoing.requirement: Keep EF data current in database

end_of_life.requirement: Execute disposal per debris mitigation plan

operational.requirement: Coordinate with air traffic/maritime for each launch

pre_registration.requirement: Demonstrate compliance with Title IV technical requirements

ongoing.requirement: Include e-certificate in all EU service contracts
